CARDINAL . DATE after LOC birth , PERSON refused to carry out the blood test . This behaviour intensified the applicant ’s suspicions regarding the child ’s paternity . He alleged that he distanced himself completely from Y and , although legally obliged to pay maintenance for her until she reached the age of majority , he had no relationship with her . This is disputed by Y ( see “ NORP The statements by Y and by the applicant ” below ) .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant legally separated from X on DATE by means of a contract of voluntary separation . Subsequently the marriage was annulled by a decree of ORG of ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant ’s version of events , on an unspecified date after DATE Y contacted him and volunteered to undergo a blood test . Scientific examinations were carried out in GPE and concluded that the applicant was not LOC biological father . However , in a written statement attached to the ORG ’s observations on the merits , Y declared that the DNA test had been carried out in DATE and not in DATE . CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an application with ORG ( FAC ) , seeking a declaration that notwithstanding the provisions of LAW , he had a right to proceed with an action for disavowal of paternity .

CARDINAL . The applicant alleged that the right to respect for his private and family life included the right to have family relationships governed by biological certainty and not by a legal presumption conflicting with the reality of the facts . He considered that the lack of any remedy in that respect violated LAW , as interpreted by ORG in the case of ORG and Others v. the GPE ( judgment of DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL-C ) .

CARDINAL . In submissions filed with ORG the applicant also invoked Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW , alleging a potential violation of his right of access to a court and his right not to be discriminated against vis - à - vis the mother of the child , the child herself or any third parties who , unlike the betrayed husband , were free to deny legitimacy without being subject to any time - limit .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG allowed the applicant ’s application . It observed that Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW had never allowed him to adduce scientific and genetic evidence to prove that the child borne by his former wife was not in fact his daughter . Therefore , there had been a violation of LAW .

CARDINAL . ORG considered that the status of father was intimately linked with private life . Therefore , laws establishing how ties of filiation could be created and dissolved could interfere with the right guaranteed by LAW . It furthermore observed that national law had never allowed the applicant to adduce scientific evidence in order for the family relationship in question to be governed by biological certainty and not by a legal presumption . In fact , under LAW , as in force at the relevant time , the father could only repudiate paternity on the grounds either of physical impossibility of cohabitation or of legal separation during the possible period of conception . Moreover , the husband could not repudiate a child on the ground of adultery , except where the birth had been concealed from him . As the applicant had been cohabiting with X at the time of ORG conception and had been aware of her birth , no action for disavowal could have been brought within DATE from the date of the birth as set forth in the relevant domestic provisions . It was true that LAW had been amended in DATE , and that under the new LAW ( d ) , the husband was also allowed to repudiate a child on the ground of adultery subject to the production of further evidence , including genetic tests , ruling out his paternity of the child . However , LAW , such an action should have been brought within DATE from the date of the birth , and by DATE that period had already expired .

CARDINAL . In ORG view , such interference could not be justified in terms of paragraph CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL of the Convention . It emphasised that in the case of ORG and Others v. the GPE ORG had stated that respect for family life required that biological and social reality should prevail over a legal presumption . This finding dispensed ORG from ascertaining whether the other rights relied on by the applicant had also been infringed .
CARDINAL . The Attorney General appealed against the judgment of CARDINAL DATE to ORG . A third - party appeal was also lodged by Y.
CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ORG allowed the appeals by the Attorney General and Y and set aside the impugned judgment .

CARDINAL . It observed that even before the DATE amendments LAW had not precluded the taking of genetic and scientific tests to establish whether a person was the father of a child or not . In fact , LAW of the LAW simply provided that adultery alone was an insufficient basis for bringing an action to repudiate paternity , the presence of another element being necessary , namely that the birth had been concealed from the person legally designated as the father . Only after this circumstance had been established could the “ father ” produce other evidence , including scientific material . The reason for this limitation of the husband ’s right to proceed with an action for repudiation had been the stand in favour of the status of legitimacy , summed up by the presumption “ pater is est quem iustae nuptiae demonstrant ” . The ratio legis remained the same even after the DATE amendments , which allowed the husband to repudiate the child on the basis of adultery and scientific tests even if the birth had not been concealed from him ( LAW ( d ) of LAW ) . In any case , scientific tests alone merely constituted evidence corroborating other elements , and they had never been sufficient and decisive to disavow paternity , the husband being obliged to prove the adultery or the concealment of the birth .

CARDINAL . ORG noted that the applicant was in reality claiming a right to determine paternity uniquely on the basis of biological certainty resulting from scientific proof , independently of any other requirement imposed by the legislator and without any time - limit . It was true that scientific tests , whose results were apparently ascertainable and accessible , could be the most conclusive ; however , in ORG view , this was not a good reason to exclude certainty reached by means of other evidence .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court examined whether the domestic law had struck a fair balance between the husband ’s right to know whether or not he was the child ’s father and the interests of the child in enjoying certainty as to his or her legal status . It considered that according to DATE ’s social trends , the aim of the interference complained of was the protection of children in the enjoyment of their family ties rather than the protection of the status of legitimacy . The issue raised by the applicant concerned a conflict between factual reality and legal certainty , a matter which was the subject of debate in many other countries . ORG noted that the Kroon and Others judgment did not deny a margin of appreciation to the ORG authorities and that ORG had not made a statement on the conformity of the provisions of NORP law with the ORG , preferring to ruleThe contested judgment had simply followed the position taken in the ORG and Others judgment , the facts of which , however , were completely different from those of the present case , in which both X and Y disagreed with the action taken by the applicant and the “ social reality ” enjoyed by Y corresponded to her birth certificate .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court moreover pointed out that in the case of PERSON v. GPE ( judgment of DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL ) the ORG had considered that the introduction of time - limits for the institution of paternity proceedings was justified by the desire to ensure legal certainty and to protect the interests of the child , and had consequently found no violation of LAW . That approach had subsequently been confirmed by ORG in the cases of GPE v. GPE ( application no . CARDINAL , decision of DATE ) and PERSON v. GPE , concerning the refusal to order a blood test ( application no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , decision of DATE ) , as well as by ORG in the case of PERSON ( DATE . ) , no . CARDINAL , DATE ) .

CARDINAL . In the light of the above , ORG considered that the interest in having biological and social reality prevail over legal presumptions should be balanced against equally valid principles and values , such as the interests of the offspring , the identity of the family nucleus and the stability of society . This vindicated the right of the ORG to impose , within its margin of appreciation , certain limits on the use of an action to deny paternity , which ORG could review only if they amounted to serious interference with the husband ’s fundamental rights .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court finally observed that the ideal situation was CARDINAL in which legal certainty corresponded to factual reality . It therefore suggested that the domestic provisions be constantly kept under the legislator ’s scrutiny to be refined and updated as and when necessary , taking into account developments in science , changes in the family and social trends .

CARDINAL . Before the DATE amendments , the relevant Articles of ORG read as follows :
“ A child conceived in wedlock is held to be the child of the mother ’s husband . ”
“ The husband can repudiate a child conceived in wedlock

( a ) if he proves that during the time from the three hundredth day to the CARDINAL - and - eightieth day before the birth of the child , he was in the physical impossibility of cohabiting with his wife on account of his being away from her , or some other accident ; or
( b ) if he proves that during the said time he was legally separated from his wife ... ”

“ The husband may not repudiate a child on the ground of adultery , except where the birth shall have been concealed from him , in which case he shall be allowed to prove , even in the action for disavowal , both the adultery and the concealment , as well as all other circumstances tending to show that he is not the father of the child ... ”
“ Where it is competent to the husband to bring an action to disown a child , he must bring such action
( a ) within DATE from DATE of the birth , if he was then in GPE ;
( b ) within DATE of his return to GPE , if he was absent at the time of the birth ;
( c ) within DATE of the discovery of the fraud , if the birth was concealed from him ... ”

CARDINAL . From DATE ( see Act XXI of DATE ) a number of amendments were made to LAW . In particular , to the cases in which the husband may repudiate a child conceived in wedlock was added the following ( LAW ( d ) of LAW ) :

“ if he proves that during the ... time [ from DATE to DATE before the birth of the child ] the wife had committed adultery or that she had concealed the pregnancy and the birth of the child , and further produces evidence of any other fact ( which may also be genetic and scientific tests and data ) that tends to exclude such paternity . ”
CARDINAL . Moreover , the periods set down in LAW were raised to DATE .

CARDINAL . By LAW , the legitimacy of a child born in wedlock may be impeached by any interested person if he or she proves that , during the time from the QUANTITY day to DATE before the birth of the child , it was physically impossible for the husband to have been cohabiting with his wife . This action is not subject to any time - limit .

CARDINAL . According to the case - law of the domestic courts , a child has the right to challenge his or her paternity without restrictions when the status attributed by the birth certificate conflicts with the factual reality ( see the judgment of ORG of DATE in the case of PERSON Dr G. GPE ) .
